entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 17 at 4:30AM CDT until August 17 at 7:30AM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Continued flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. This advisory will replace the Flash Flood Warning that was in effect.
* WHERE...Portions of northeast Illinois, including the following counties, Cook and DuPage and northwest Indiana, including the following county, Lake IN.
* WHEN...Until 730 AM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Flooding may continue in poor drainage and urban areas, including flooded underpasses, roads, and streets.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 428 AM CDT, Doppler radar and gauge estimates between 2 and 4 inches of rain have fallen. Scattered thunderstorms are occurring over portions of the advisory area. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Chicago, Naperville, Cicero, Hammond, Gary, Arlington Heights, Schaumburg, Des Plaines, Orland Park, Oak Lawn, Berwyn, Mount Prospect, Wheaton, Oak Park, Downers Grove, Elmhurst, Lombard, Bartlett, Ohare Airport and Carol Stream. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cook, IL; DuPage, IL; Lake, IN

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 17 at 5:28AM AST until August 18 at 8:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
...The risk for flash and urban flooding, along with landslides or mudslides continues...
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall and runoff continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands
* WHEN...Through Monday evening.
* IMPACTS...Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - The outer bands of Erin will continue to produce areas of heavy rainfall today across the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches, with isolated totals of 8 inches, are expected. Locally considerable flash and urban flooding, along with landslides or mudslides, are possible. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; Southeast; Eastern Interior; North Central; Central Interior; Ponce and Vicinity; Northwest; Western Interior; Mayaguez and Vicinity; Southwest; Culebra; Vieques; St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands; St Croix

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 17 at 4:27AM CDT until August 19 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Wisconsin...
Fox River Lower At Waukesha affecting Waukesha County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Fox River Lower at Waukesha.
* WHEN...Until early Tuesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 6.0 feet, There is minor lowland flooding in the Waukesha area.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM CDT Sunday the stage was 6.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 5.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 AM CDT Sunday was 6.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 6.2 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 6.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 6.2 feet on 04/24/1999. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 17 at 5:25AM EDT until August 17 at 11:00PM EDT by NWS Northern Indiana
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous swimming conditions expected, especially by late afternoon as winds shift to the north.
*Waves of 1 to 2 feet will build to 3 to 4 feet through the day.
*Life-threatening rip and structural currents are expected. Structural currents will be especially strong on the north side of piers and breakwalls.
*A strong southward flowing longshore current is expected by the afternoon.
* WHERE...In Indiana, Northern La Porte county. In Michigan, Southern Berrien county.
* WHEN...From noon EDT /11 AM CDT/ today through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Strong currents can pull swimmers into deeper water and high waves can sweep people off piers.
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION...
Strong thunderstorms over Lake Michigan overnight into this morning led to water level fluctuations at nearby gauges, suggesting seiche or meteotsunami activity was ongoing. This activity (largely unnoticeable visually) may persist through the evening, increasing the likelihood and strength of dangerous currents-even during periods of wave heights less than 3 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern La Porte; Southern Berrien

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM NOON EDT /11 AM CDT/ TODAY THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued August 17 at 5:07AM AST until August 18 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 8 to 14 feet. For the HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK, life-threatening rip current.
* WHERE... For the HIGH SURF ADVISORY, the most vulnerable areas for high surf and beach erosion include Pinones along Road 187, Parcelas Suarez, Villas del Mar, and Villa Christiana in Loiza; Fortuna in Luquillo; Pueblo and Tamarindo in Aguadilla; Barrio Obrero, Pueblo and Jareaito in Arecibo; Las Boca in Barceloneta; Machuca in Manati; Puerto Nuevo in Vega Baja; Ocean Park in San Juan; and Barrio Espinal in Aguada. For the HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK along the north and east-facing beaches.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory remains until 6 AM AST Monday. For the High Rip Current Risk remains through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...FOR THE HIGH SURF ADVISORY, High waves that can wash over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks. Rough surf may also knock you down. Large breaking waves will result in localized beach/dune structure erosion and dangerous swimming conditions. FOR THE HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK, rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water, where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; North Central; Northwest; Culebra; Vieques; St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands; St Croix

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 16 at 9:09PM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog, with visibilities as low as a few hundred feet, can be expected overnight. The dense fog is expected to continue through daybreak before lifting.
Motorists traveling across the region tonight can expect locally hazardous travel conditions, with rapidly changing and very poor visibilities at times. Remember to slow down, turn on your low- beam headlights, and keep a safe distance between you and the car in front of you.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 16 at 3:17PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Strong northwesterly winds up to 45 mph continue to resuspend ash from the 1912 Katmai-Novarupta eruption across Shelikof Strait. Communities on southern Kodiak Island, including Karluk and Larsen Bay, will observe reduced visibility as a result of the ash.
Those with respiratory ailments in these areas are encouraged to avoid or reduce outdoor activity to avoid inhaling the ash. Winds will gradually diminish through Sunday night, which should allow ash impacts to cease sometime on Sunday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kodiak Island Southwest

cap:parameter.value: RESUSPENDED ASH FROM KATMAI-NOVARUPTA OVER KODIAK ISLAND THROUGH SUNDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 15 at 4:51PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Strong northwesterly winds up to 45 mph have developed across Shelikof Strait. These winds are resuspending ash from the 1912 Katmai-Novarupta eruption. The villages of Karluk and Larsen Bay are most likely to be impacted. Ash is currently north of Akhiok, but ash may mix south to the area.
Those with respiratory ailments in these areas are encouraged to avoid or reduce outdoor activity to avoid inhaling the ash through late this evening. The winds will diminish Sunday morning, which should allow the ash to settle out of the atmosphere.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kodiak Island Southwest

cap:parameter.value: RESUSPENDED ASH FROM KATMAI-NOVARUPTA EXPECTED OVER KODIAK ISLAND THROUGH SUNDAY MORNING
